video: Watch Malala Yousafzai's Nobel Peace Prize acceptance speech

captions.caption: The image shows a person standing at a lectern, speaking into a microphone. The individual is wearing a pink hijab and a pink garment that could be a dress or a top. The background is a simple blue wall with a pattern that resembles a grid or a network. There is a red banner with white text at the bottom of the image, which reads "Malala Yousafzai Nobel Laureate." The style of the image suggests it is a still from a video or a photograph taken during a public speaking event. The focus is on the person, and the background is out of focus, emphasizing the speaker.

fused_results.asr: Dear brothers and sisters, I was named after the inspirational Malalai of Mewand, who is the Pashtun Joan of Arc. The word Malala means grief-stricken, sad, but in order to lend some happiness to it, my grandfather would always call me Malala, the happiest girl in the world. And today, I am very happy that we are together fighting for an important cause.

fused_results.asr: just for me. It is for those forgotten children who want education. It is for those frightened children who want peace. It is for those voiceless children who want change. I'm here to stand up for their rights, to raise their voice. It is not time to pity them. It is not time to pity them. It is time to take action. So it becomes the last time, the last time. So it becomes the last time that we see a child deprived of education.

fused_results.asr: I have found that people describe me in many different ways. Some people call me the girl who was shot by the Taliban. And some, the girl who fought for her rights. Some people call me a Nobel laureate now. However, my brothers still call me that annoying bossy sister. As far as I know, I'm just a committed and even stubborn person who wants to see every child getting quality education, who wants to see women having equal rights, and who wants peace in every corner of the world.
